Paragraph.Text: may direct that no contract by the terms of which payments are required in excess of such amount or amounts as the Governor in Council may prescribe shall be entered into or have any force or effect unless entry into the contract has been approved by the Governor in Council or the Treasury Board; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: may make regulations with respect to the security to be given to and in the name of Her Majesty to secure the due performance of contracts.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of Crown corporations or the Canada Revenue Agency.

The Governor in Council may make regulations fixing terms that are deemed to be expressly set out in contracts, or classes of contracts, that provide for the payment of any money by Her Majesty or a Crown corporation — or in documents, or classes of documents, relating to such contracts and their formation — including terms

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prohibiting payment of a contingency fee by any party to the contract to a person to whom the Lobbying Act applies;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: respecting corruption and collusion in the bidding process for contracts for the performance of work, the supply of goods or the rendering of services;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: requiring that a bidder on a contract for the performance of work, the supply of goods or the rendering of services make a declaration that the bidder has not committed an offence under section 121, 124 or 418 of the Criminal Code;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the provision of information or records to enable the Auditor General of Canada to inquire into the use of funds provided under funding agreements; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: requiring the public disclosure of basic information on contracts entered into with Her Majesty for the performance of work, the supply of goods or the rendering of services and having a value in excess of $10,000.

Subsection.Text: Regulations made under subsection (1) may not infringe on the powers of the Auditor General under section 7.1 of the Auditor General Act.
The Governor in Council may, in respect of contracts for public opinion research, make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the form and content of the term of the contract and of the written report referred to in subsection 40(2); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: requiring the report to be made available to the public in the manner, and subject to the conditions, specified in the regulations.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this section.

Definition.Text: funding agreement, in respect of a recipient, means an agreement in writing under which the recipient receives a grant, contribution or other funding from Her Majesty in right of Canada or a Crown corporation, either directly or through an agent or mandatary of Her Majesty, including by way of loan, but excludes contracts for the performance of work, the supply of goods or the rendering of services.

recipient means an individual, body corporate, partnership or unincorporated organization that has, in any five consecutive fiscal years, received a total of one million dollars or more under one or more funding agreements, but does not include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a Crown corporation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a departmental corporation;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the government of a foreign state, a provincial government or a municipality, or any of their agencies;

Paragraph.Label: (c.1)
Paragraph.Text: a band, as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Indian Act, any member of the council or any agency of the band or an aboriginal body that is party to a self-government agreement given effect by an Act of Parliament or any of their agencies;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a corporation that is controlled by a municipality or a government other than the Government of Canada; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an international organization.

Subsection.Text: Subject to and except as otherwise provided in any directives issued by the Treasury Board, every department shall conduct a review every five years of the relevance and effectiveness of each ongoing program for which it is responsible.

In this section, program means a program of grants or contributions made to one or more recipients that are administered so as to achieve a common objective and for which spending authority is provided in an appropriation Act.

Notwithstanding any statement in any other Act of Parliament to the effect that this Act or any portion or provision of it does not apply, no money shall be borrowed by or on behalf of Her Majesty in right of Canada except as provided by or under

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any other Act of Parliament that expressly authorizes the borrowing of money; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any other Act of Parliament that provides for the borrowing of money from Her Majesty in right of Canada or of a province.

Subsection.Text: No securities shall be issued by or on behalf of Her Majesty in right of Canada without the authority of Parliament.

Section.Text: The Governor in Council may authorize the Minister to borrow money on behalf of Her Majesty in right of Canada.

Subsection.Text: When by this Act or any other Act of Parliament authority is given to raise money by Her Majesty, the Governor in Council may, subject to the Act authorizing the raising of the money, authorize the Minister to borrow the money by any means that the Minister considers appropriate.

The aggregate principal amount of money borrowed by the Minister under this section in any fiscal year may not exceed the amount that is specified by order of the Governor in Council for that fiscal year.

Subject to any terms and conditions that the Governor in Council may specify, the Minister may enter into any contract or agreement, issue securities and do any other thing relating to the borrowing of money that the Minister considers appropriate.

Subsection (3) applies with respect to anything done in relation to borrowings under this section, as it read immediately before the coming into force of this subsection, as though the borrowing were done under subsection (1).
If the Minister borrows money by way of an auction, the Minister may establish rules governing the conduct of the auction, including rules relating to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the eligibility of persons to participate in the auction;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the provision to the Minister by participants of any information that the Minister considers relevant, including information respecting holdings of securities and transactions in securities;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the form of bids;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the maximum amount that may be bid for by a participant; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the certification and verification of bids.

Subsection.Text: Rules governing the conduct of an auction are not statutory instruments as defined in the Statutory Instruments Act.

Section.Text: The Governor in Council may authorize the Minister, subject to any terms and conditions that the Governor in Council may specify, to enter into any contract or agreement of a financial nature, including options, derivatives, swaps and forwards, on such terms and conditions as the Minister considers necessary.

Section.MarginalNote: Powers — management of assets and liabilities
Section.Text: The Minister may, on any terms and conditions the Minister considers appropriate, do any of the following if the Minister considers it appropriate for the sound and efficient management of the assets and liabilities of Canada, including contingent liabilities:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: purchase or acquire securities of Canada or any other securities, including purchasing or acquiring them on their issuance, and hold, lend or sell securities of Canada or any other securities; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: create a charge on, or right or interest in, securities of Canada or any other securities held by the Minister.

Subsection.Text: Any amounts raised by way of loan under the authority of this Act or any other Act of Parliament in the currency or currencies of any country or countries may be repaid in the currency or currencies of any country or countries and securities issued under the authority of this Act or any other Act of Parliament in the currency or currencies of any country or countries may be made payable in the currency or currencies of any country or countries.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Calculation of amount in foreign currency
Subsection.Text: Where an Act of Parliament, whether enacted before or after the coming into force of this subsection, authorizes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the raising of a specific or maximum number of dollars by way of loan or the issue of securities, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the guarantee of the payment of a liability or obligation for a specific or maximum number of dollars,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the authorized transaction may be undertaken, in whole or in part, in the currency of a country other than Canada, and for that purpose the specific or maximum number of dollars shall be construed as an equivalent amount in the currency of the other country, calculated at the rate of exchange between the Canadian dollar and the currency concerned as quoted by the Bank of Canada at noon on the day immediately preceding the day on which the money is borrowed, the proceeds from the issue of securities are received or the guarantee is given, as the case may be.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of any limitation in respect of an amount

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that may be borrowed,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for which securities may be issued, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the payment of which may be guaranteed under this Act or any other Act of Parliament,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the principal amount borrowed or authorized to be borrowed, the principal amount of any securities previously issued or authorized to be issued or the amount guaranteed or authorized to be guaranteed, as the case may be, payable in a currency of any country other than Canada, shall be deemed to be the Canadian dollar equivalent of the value thereof, as calculated under subsection (2), regardless of any premium or discount at which the securities were sold and regardless of any premium that may be payable on early redemption.

Subsection.Text: After the Public Accounts are tabled in the House of Commons, the Minister shall cause to be tabled in each House of Parliament, within the first 30 days on which that House is sitting after the Public Accounts are tabled in the House of Commons, a report on the activities of the Minister in relation to the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the money borrowed under section 43.1 in the fiscal year to which the Public Accounts relate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the management of the public debt in the fiscal year to which the Public Accounts relate.

Subsection.Text: In every fiscal year, the Minister shall cause to be tabled in each House of Parliament a report on the Minister’s plans in relation to the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the money to be borrowed under section 43.1 in the next fiscal year and the purposes for which the moneys will be borrowed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the management of the public debt in the next fiscal year.

Subsection.Text: Security certificates evidencing securities issued under the authority of this Part shall be signed by the Deputy Minister of Finance or an officer of the Department of Finance designated by the Governor in Council to sign on behalf of the Deputy Minister of Finance, and shall be countersigned by such officer of the Department of Finance or other person as the Governor in Council designates for that purpose.

The Minister may direct that there be substituted for signatures in the proper handwriting of one or both of the persons authorized to sign or countersign security certificates under subsection (1), facsimiles of those signatures.
The Governor in Council may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: appoint one or more registrars to perform such services in respect of the registration of loans as the Governor in Council may prescribe;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: appoint one or more fiscal agents to perform such services in respect of loans as the Governor in Council may prescribe; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: fix the remuneration or compensation of any registrar or fiscal agent appointed under this section.

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may authorize the Minister to do anything referred to in paragraphs (1)(a) to (c) for any period that the Governor in Council considers appropriate.
The Minister shall cause to be maintained a system of books and records

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: showing all money authorized by Parliament to be borrowed by the issue and sale of securities;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: containing a description and record of all money so borrowed and securities issued; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: showing all amounts paid in respect of the principal of or interest on all money so borrowed.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Accounting by fiscal agents and registrars
Subsection.Text: Every fiscal agent and registrar shall annually, and as often as required by the Minister, give to the Minister an accounting, in such form and terms and containing such information as the Minister prescribes, of all his transactions as fiscal agent or registrar.

Section.Text: The Governor in Council may provide for the creation and management of a sinking fund with respect to any issue of securities or with respect to all securities issued.

The repayment of all money borrowed and interest on that money, including the principal of and interest on all securities issued by or on behalf of Her Majesty with the authority of Parliament, is a charge on and payable out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund.
With the authority of the Governor in Council, there may be paid out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all money required under section 53 to provide a sinking fund or other means of securing repayment of securities;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the remuneration and compensation of registrars and fiscal agents appointed under section 51;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all costs, expenses and charges incurred in the negotiation or raising of loans or in the issue, redemption, servicing, payment and management of any loan and any securities issued in respect thereof; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all money required to be paid under contracts and agreements entered into under this Part, either before or after the coming into force of this paragraph.

Section.MarginalNote: Payment for securities to agent or by salary deduction in trust money

Subsection.Text: Where it is provided by a prospectus or other official notice issued by or under the authority of the Minister that a subscriber may purchase securities by payments to an authorized agent or by deductions from the remuneration of the subscriber by his employer, the amount of any such payment or deduction that has not been accounted for by the delivery of securities to the subscriber or repaid to the subscriber shall be deemed to be money received in trust for Her Majesty by the agent or employer for which the agent or employer is accountable to Her Majesty under section 76.

Where money paid or deducted pursuant to subsection (1) cannot be identified among the assets of the employer or agent, a portion of those assets equal in value to the amount of the payment or deduction shall be deemed to be segregated and held in trust for Her Majesty.

Section.Text: There shall be established in the accounts of Canada an account to be known as the Investors’ Indemnity Account to which shall be credited the sum of twenty-five thousand dollars, such further amounts as are appropriated by Parliament for the purposes of this section and any recoveries of the losses referred to in section 58.

The Minister may, in accordance with and subject to the regulations, pay out of the Investors’ Indemnity Account any losses sustained by subscribers for securities who have paid all or part of the purchase price for those securities but have not received the security or repayment of the amount so paid, and losses sustained by any person in the redemption of securities.
Her Majesty and a fiscal agent or registrar acting as such are not bound to see to the execution of any express or implied trust to which any securities are subject.

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may make such regulations as he deems necessary to provide for the management of the public debt of Canada and the payment of interest thereon and, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, may make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the inscription of security certificates and the registration of securities and prescribing the effect of the inscription or registration;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for the transmission, transfer, redemption and cancellation of securities and the exchange and destruction of any security certificates, and, without limiting the generality of the foregoing,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for the transmission, transfer or redemption of securities pursuant to a judgment or as the result of the death, dissolution or bankruptcy of the registered owner of the securities, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: prescribing the conditions on which the transfer and redemption of securities or the exchange of security certificates registered in the names of infants, minors or other persons not of full capacity to enter into ordinary contracts may be made;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for the issue of security certificates or making of payments in respect of damaged, lost, stolen or destroyed security certificates or interest coupons, and of the cheques pertaining thereto and prescribing conditions to the issue or payment;

Paragraph.Label: (c.1)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the issuance and holding of non-certificated securities;

Paragraph.Label: (c.2)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the circumstances under which the beneficial owner of a non-certificated security can obtain a security certificate or under which the beneficial owner of a security certificate can obtain a non-certificated security;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: requiring guarantees to be given to the registrar in such manner and by such persons as the regulations may prescribe, before the registrar is authorized to make any entry in the register;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: authorizing the correction by the registrar, in such circumstances as may be prescribed by the regulations, of errors in the register and otherwise authorizing rectification of the register;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: providing for the payment of losses out of the Investors’ Indemnity Account;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: deeming a specified transaction or a transaction of a specified class, including the issuance of securities, to be a transaction to borrow money for the purposes of subsection 43(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: notwithstanding any right provided by or under any other Act of Parliament to borrow money without the Minister’s authorization, requiring the Minister’s authorization in respect of a specified transaction to borrow money or a transaction of a specified class to borrow money.

Subsection.Text: The register maintained pursuant to subsection (1) may be in a bound or loose-leaf form or in a photographic film form or may be maintained by any system of mechanical or electronic data processing or any other information storage device that is capable of reproducing any required information in intelligible written form within a reasonable time.

The register maintained pursuant to subsection (1) is deemed to be a record for the purposes of the Canada Evidence Act and every employee of the Bank of Canada who supervises the inscription or registration of securities in the register is deemed to be a manager of the Bank of Canada for the purposes of that Act.
If a regulation is made under paragraph (1)(g) or (h), the Minister may authorize, subject to any terms and conditions that the Minister considers appropriate,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the specified transaction;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a particular transaction named by the Minister within the specified class;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: transactions of a particular subclass described by the Minister within the specified class; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: transactions of the specified class.

Section.Text: The Minister may delegate to any officer of the Department of Finance any of the powers, duties and functions of the Minister under this Part, except the power to delegate under this section.

Heading.Label: PART IV.1
Heading.TitleText: Stability and Efficiency of the Financial System

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this section.

Definition.Text: debt obligation means a bond, debenture, note or other evidence of indebtedness of an entity, whether secured or unsecured.
entity means an entity that, in the Minister’s opinion, is operating in Canada.
financial markets includes markets for money, bonds, equities, derivatives, foreign exchange and commodities.
financial system includes financial institutions, financial markets and payment systems as defined in section 36 of the Canadian Payments Act.
security means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to a corporation, a share, a class of shares or a debt obligation of the corporation, and includes any conversion or exchange privilege, option or other right to acquire a share of the corporation; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to any other entity, any ownership interest in or debt obligation of the entity.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), the Minister may, with the Governor in Council’s authorization, enter into, on behalf of Her Majesty in right of Canada, any contract that in the Minister’s opinion is necessary to promote the stability or maintain the efficiency of the financial system in Canada, including such a contract to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: purchase, acquire, hold, lend or sell or otherwise dispose of securities of an entity;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: create a charge on, or right or interest in, securities of an entity held by the Minister;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: make a loan to an entity;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: provide a line of credit to an entity;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: guarantee any debt, obligation or financial asset of an entity; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: provide loan insurance or credit insurance for the benefit of an entity in respect of any debt, obligation or financial asset of the entity.

Subsection.Text: Paragraph (2)(a) does not apply to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shares, as defined in subsection 973.2(15) of the Bank Act, of a bank or bank holding company, as defined in section 2 of that Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shares, as defined in subsection 459.9(14) of the Cooperative Credit Associations Act, of an association as defined in section 2 of that Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: shares, as defined in subsection 1016.7(15) of the Insurance Companies Act, of a company or insurance holding company, as defined in subsection 2(1) of that Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: shares, as defined in subsection 527.9(15) of the Trust and Loan Companies Act, of a company as defined in section 2 of that Act.

Subsection.Text: Section 90 does not apply if the Minister purchases, acquires or sells or otherwise disposes, under paragraph (2)(a), of shares within the meaning of that section.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Section 61 and Surplus Crown Assets Act do not apply
Subsection.Text: Section 61 and the Surplus Crown Assets Act do not apply if the Minister holds, loans or sells or otherwise disposes of securities under paragraph (2)(a).

Any amount payable under or in connection with a contract entered into under this section may be paid out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund, on the requisition of the Minister, at the times and in the manner that the Minister considers appropriate.
This section applies to any contract entered into on or after November 30, 2008.

Subject to any other Act of Parliament, no transfer, lease or loan of public property shall be made except under the Federal Real Property and Federal Immovables Act in the case of federal real property or a federal immovable as defined in that Act, or under subsection (2) in the case of other public property.

The Governor in Council, on the recommendation of the Treasury Board, may authorize or make regulations authorizing the transfer, lease or loan of public property other than federal real property and federal immovables as defined in the Federal Real Property and Federal Immovables Act.

Section.Text: The deputy head of every department shall maintain adequate records in relation to public property for which the department is responsible and shall comply with regulations of the Treasury Board governing the custody and control of public property.

Subsection.Text: Subject to regulations of the Treasury Board, the Receiver General shall cause accounts to be kept in such manner as to show

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the expenditures made under each appropriation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the revenues of Canada; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the other payments into and out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

Subsection.Text: The Receiver General shall cause accounts to be kept to show such of the assets and direct and contingent liabilities of Canada and shall establish such reserves with respect to the assets and liabilities as, in the opinion of the President of the Treasury Board and the Minister, are required to present fairly the financial position of Canada.
The accounts of Canada shall be kept in the currency of Canada.

Section.MarginalNote: Submission of Public Accounts to Parliament

Subsection.Text: A report, called the Public Accounts, shall be prepared by the Receiver General for each fiscal year and shall be laid before the House of Commons by the President of the Treasury Board on or before December 31 next following the end of that fiscal year or, if the House of Commons is not then sitting, on any of the first fifteen days next thereafter that the House of Commons is sitting.
The Public Accounts shall be in such form as the President of the Treasury Board and the Minister may direct, and shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the financial transactions of the fiscal year,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the expenditures and revenues of Canada for the fiscal year, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: such of the assets and liabilities of Canada as, in the opinion of the President of the Treasury Board and the Minister, are required to show the financial position of Canada as at the termination of the fiscal year;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the contingent liabilities of Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the opinion of the Auditor General of Canada as required under section 6 of the Auditor General Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: such other accounts and information relating to the fiscal year as are deemed necessary by the President of the Treasury Board and the Minister to present fairly the financial transactions and the financial position of Canada or as are required by this Act or any other Act of Parliament to be shown in the Public Accounts.

Section.Text: For the purpose of the keeping of the accounts of Canada under section 63 and the preparation of the Public Accounts under section 64, the Receiver General may, from time to time, subject to such regulations as the Treasury Board may make, send a notice to each appropriate Minister requesting such records, accounts or statements or other information as is specified in the notice and each appropriate Minister shall, within such reasonable time as is specified in the notice, provide the Receiver General with the records, accounts or statements or other information requested.

Subsection.Text: Every department shall cause to be prepared, in the form and manner provided for by the Treasury Board, a quarterly financial report for each of the first three fiscal quarters of each fiscal year.
The report shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a financial statement for the fiscal quarter and the period from the start of the fiscal year to the end of that fiscal quarter;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: comparative financial information for the preceding fiscal year; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a statement outlining the results, risks and significant changes in relation to operations, personnel and programs.

Subsection.Text: The appropriate Minister shall cause the report to be made public within 60 days after the end of the fiscal quarter to which the report relates.
The Treasury Board may, by regulation, exempt a department from the requirement set out in subsection (1) or provide that any of the content referred to in subsection (2) be excluded from its report.

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: appropriate paying officer, in relation to a Crown debt, means the paying officer who makes the payments in respect of that debt;
contract means a contract involving the payment of money by the Crown;
Crown means Her Majesty in right of Canada;
Crown debt means any existing or future debt due or becoming due by the Crown, and any other chose in action in respect of which there is a right of recovery enforceable by action against the Crown;
paying officer means any person designated as such by regulation;
prescribed means prescribed by regulation.

Section.Text: Except as provided in this Act or any other Act of Parliament,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a Crown debt is not assignable; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: no transaction purporting to be an assignment of a Crown debt is effective so as to confer on any person any rights or remedies in respect of that debt.

Subsection.Text: Subject to this section, an assignment may be made of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a Crown debt that is an amount due or becoming due under a contract; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any other Crown debt of a prescribed class.

Subsection.Text: The assignment referred to in subsection (1) is valid only if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it is absolute, in writing and made under the hand of the assignor;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it does not purport to be by way of charge only; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: notice of the assignment has been given to the Crown as provided in section 69.

Subsection.Text: The assignment referred to in subsections (1) and (2) is effectual in law, subject to all equities that would have been entitled to priority over the right of the assignee if this section had not been enacted, to pass and transfer, from the date service on the Crown of notice of the assignment is effected,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the legal right to the Crown debt;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all legal and other remedies for the Crown debt; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the power to give a good discharge for the Crown debt without the concurrence of the assignor.

Subsection.Text: An assignment made in accordance with this Part is subject to all conditions and restrictions in respect of the right of transfer that relate to the original Crown debt or that attach to or are contained in the original contract.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Salary, wages, pay and allowances not assignable
Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding subsection (1), any amount due or becoming due by the Crown as or on account of salary, wages, pay or pay and allowances is not assignable and no transaction purporting to be an assignment of any such amount is effective to confer on any person any rights or remedies in respect of that amount.

The notice referred to in paragraph 68(2)(c) shall be given to the Crown by serving on or sending by registered mail to the Receiver General or a paying officer, in prescribed form, notice of the assignment, together with a copy of the assignment accompanied by such other documents completed in such manner as may be prescribed.

Service of the notice referred to in subsection (1) shall be deemed not to have been effected until acknowledgment of the notice, in prescribed form, is sent to the assignee, by registered mail, under the hand of the appropriate paying officer.

Section.MarginalNote: Limitation of application of this Part
Section.Text: This Part does not apply

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to any negotiable instrument;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to any Crown debt incurred by or in the name of a corporation set out in Schedule III; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to any securities issued under Part IV.

Section.Text: The Governor in Council may make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: designating persons as paying officers for the purposes of this Part;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing additional classes of Crown debts for the purpose of subsection 68(1);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the forms of notices of assignment and acknowledgments thereof;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the documents to be submitted in connection with a notice of assignment, the forms of those documents and the manner in which they are to be completed; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: generally, for carrying into effect the purposes and provisions of this Part.

Heading.Label: PART VIII
Heading.TitleText: Assignment of Debts Due to the Crown Under Payment Bonds

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: Crown means Her Majesty in right of Canada or any agent of Her Majesty in right of Canada and includes a Crown corporation and a departmental corporation;

payment bond means a bond held by the Crown as security for the payment of certain classes of persons who perform labour or services or supply material in connection with a contract between the Crown and a contractor.

Section.MarginalNote: Assignment of Crown right under payment bond

Subsection.Text: Where an amount is due to the Crown under the provisions of a payment bond, a person who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: performed labour or services or supplied material in connection with the contract in respect of which the payment bond is held,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is within a class of persons for the payment of which the payment bond is held as security, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has not been paid in full for the labour or services performed or material supplied by him in connection with the contract within the time provided in the payment bond for payment to the class of persons of which that person is a member,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is, without any act by or notice by or to the Crown, an assignee of the right of the Crown to recover an amount under the payment bond determined pursuant to subsection (2).

Subsection.Text: The amount that may be recovered by a person referred to in subsection (1) shall be equal to the lesser of the amount due to that person for the labour or services performed or material supplied by him under the contract and the amount due to the Crown under the provisions of the payment bond.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Crown not a party to action
Subsection.Text: A person who is an assignee of the right of the Crown to recover an amount under a payment bond may, in his own name, exercise the right that, but for this Act, the Crown would have had to bring action to enforce payment under the payment bond in accordance with its terms and conditions and the Crown shall be neither a party to, nor liable for any costs in connection with, that action.

Section.MarginalNote: Provision of certified copy of payment bond

Subsection.Text: A copy of a payment bond certified by the officer of the Crown having custody of the original payment bond shall be provided by that officer to any person who files with him an affidavit setting out that the person has performed labour or services or supplied material in connection with the contract for which the bond is held and that he has not been paid in full therefor.

A document purporting to be a copy of a payment bond certified by the officer of the Crown having custody of the original payment bond is, without proof of the signature of the officer, admissible in evidence in any court of justice, or before a person having by law or by consent of parties authority to hear, receive and examine evidence in any action taken by a person under this Part, and has the same probative force as the original document would have if it were proven in the ordinary way.

Section.Text: The Governor in Council, on the recommendation of the Treasury Board, may make regulations for carrying into effect the purposes and provisions of this Part.

Section.MarginalNote: Notice to persons failing to pay over public money

Subsection.Text: Where the appropriate Minister or the Receiver General believes on reasonable grounds that any person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has received money for Her Majesty and has not duly paid it over,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has received money for which the person is accountable to Her Majesty and has not duly accounted for it, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has received any public money applicable to any purpose and has not duly applied it,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the appropriate Minister or the Receiver General, as the case may be, may cause a notice to be served on that person, or on the person’s representative in case of the person’s death, requiring the person, within such time after the service of the notice as may be named therein, duly to pay over, account for or apply that money, as the case may be, and to transmit to the appropriate Minister or the Receiver General, as the notice provides, proper vouchers that the person has done so.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Proceedings where notice not complied with
Subsection.Text: Where a person does not comply with a notice served under subsection (1), the appropriate Minister or the Receiver General, as the case may be, shall state an account between that person and Her Majesty showing the amount of money not duly paid over, accounted for or applied, as the case may be, and may charge interest on the whole or any part of that amount from such date as the appropriate Minister or the Receiver General may determine and at such rate as may be prescribed pursuant to subsection 155.1(6).

In any proceedings for the recovery of money referred to in subsection (2), a copy of the account stated and certified by the appropriate Minister or the Receiver General is evidence that the amount stated in the account, together with interest, is due and payable to Her Majesty, without proof of the signature of the appropriate Minister or the Receiver General or the official character of the office.
Any amount of money referred to in subsection (1) and the interest on that amount may be recovered as a debt due to Her Majesty.

Section.Text: Where it appears by the books or accounts kept by or in the office of any person employed in the collection or management of the revenue, in any accounting by that person or by his written acknowledgment or confession, that that person has, by virtue of his office or employment, received money belonging to Her Majesty and refused or neglected to pay over that money to the proper persons at the proper times, an affidavit deposing to those facts, taken by any person having knowledge thereof, shall, in any proceedings for the recovery of that money, be admitted in evidence and is, in the absence of any evidence to the contrary, proof of the facts stated therein.

Where, by reason of any malfeasance or negligence by any person employed in collecting or receiving any public money, any sum of money is lost to Her Majesty, that person is accountable for the sum as if that person had collected and received it and it may be recovered from that person as if that person had collected and received it.

Section.MarginalNote: Regulations in respect of losses of money and public property
Section.Text: The Governor in Council, on the recommendation of the Treasury Board, may make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the actions to be taken in respect of losses of money or public property, however caused, suffered by Her Majesty;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the charging of losses of money suffered by Her Majesty against the appropriations to which they relate; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the records to be kept and providing for the reporting in the Public Accounts in respect of every loss referred to in paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: Every officer or person acting in any office or employment connected with the collection, management or disbursement of public money who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: receives any compensation or reward for the performance of any official duty, except as by law prescribed,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conspires or colludes with any other person to defraud Her Majesty, or makes opportunity for any person to defraud Her Majesty,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: designedly permits any contravention of the law by any other person,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: wilfully makes or signs any false entry in any book, or wilfully makes or signs any false certificate or return in any case in which it is the duty of that officer or person to make an entry, certificate or return,

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: having knowledge or information of the contravention of this Act or the regulations or any revenue law of Canada by any person, or of fraud committed by any person against Her Majesty, under this Act or the regulations or any revenue law of Canada, fails to report, in writing, that knowledge or information to a superior officer, or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: demands or accepts or attempts to collect, directly or indirectly, as payment or gift or otherwise, any sum of money, or other thing of value, for the compromise, adjustment or settlement of any charge or complaint for any contravention or alleged contravention of law,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding five thousand dollars and to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years.

Subsection.Text: Every officer or person acting in any office or employment connected with the collection, management or disbursement of public money who, by deceit, falsehood or other fraudulent means, defrauds Her Majesty of any money, securities, property or service is guilty of an indictable offence and liable on conviction,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the amount of the money or the value of the securities, property or service does not exceed $5,000, to a fine not exceeding $5,000 and to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the amount of the money or the value of the securities, property or service exceeds $5,000, to a fine not exceeding that amount or that value and to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

Section.MarginalNote: Idem, where bribes offered or accepted
Section.Text: Every person who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: promises, offers or gives any bribe to any officer or any person acting in any office or employment connected with the collection, management or disbursement of public money, with intent

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: to influence the decision or action of that officer or person on any question or matter that is then pending, or may, by law, be brought before him in his official capacity, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: to influence that officer or person to commit, or aid or abet in committing any fraud on the revenue, or to connive at, collude in, or allow or permit any opportunity for the commission of any such fraud, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: accepts or receives any such bribe,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding three times the amount so offered or accepted and to imprisonment for any term not exceeding five years.

Section.MarginalNote: Books, etc., property of Her Majesty
Section.Text: All books, papers, accounts and documents kept or used by, or received or taken into the possession of, any officer or person who is or has been employed in the collection or management of the revenue or in accounting for the revenue, by virtue of that employment, shall be deemed to be chattels belonging to Her Majesty, and all money or valuable securities received or taken into the possession of that officer or person by virtue of his employment shall be deemed to be money and valuable securities belonging to Her Majesty.

Subsection.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: agent corporation means a Crown corporation that is expressly declared by or pursuant to any other Act of Parliament to be an agent of the Crown;
appoint includes elect and designate;
appropriate Minister means,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to a parent Crown corporation,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the Minister specified by or pursuant to any other Act of Parliament as the Minister in respect of that corporation, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if no Minister is specified as described in subparagraph (i), such member of the Queen’s Privy Council for Canada as is designated by order of the Governor in Council as the appropriate Minister for the corporation, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to a wholly-owned subsidiary, the appropriate Minister, as defined in paragraph (a), for the parent Crown corporation that wholly owns the subsidiary;

Definition.Text: articles means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: original or restated articles of incorporation, articles of amendment, articles of amalgamation, articles of continuance, articles of reorganization, articles of arrangement, articles of dissolution and articles of revival, and includes any amendments thereto, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: letters patent, memorandum of association and any constating documents or other documents of a like nature to those referred to in paragraph (a), and includes any amendments thereto;

Definition.Text: auditor includes a partnership of auditors;
board of directors means a board of directors, by whatever name called, of a corporation and includes a group of persons, other than a minister of the Crown, that constitutes a corporation;
by-law means a by-law, by whatever name called, of a corporation and includes an amendment or a repeal of a by-law;
chairperson means a person occupying the position of chairperson, by whatever name called, of the board of directors of a corporation;
charter means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to a corporation established by an Act of Parliament, the Act, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to a corporation established by articles, the articles;

Definition.Text: corporation includes a company or other body corporate wherever or however incorporated;
Crown means Her Majesty in right of Canada;
Crown corporation means a parent Crown corporation or a wholly-owned subsidiary;

director means a person occupying the position of director, by whatever name called, of a corporation and includes any person, other than a minister of the Crown, in a group of persons that constitutes a corporation;

major business or activity, in relation to a parent Crown corporation or a wholly-owned subsidiary, means a class of business or activity of the corporation or subsidiary established pursuant to subsection (10) or, if no classes are so established, all the business or activity of the corporation or subsidiary;
parent Crown corporation means a corporation that is wholly owned directly by the Crown, but does not include a departmental corporation;
regulations means the regulations made under this Part;
share includes a membership interest or ownership interest in a corporation;

wholly-owned subsidiary means a corporation that is wholly owned by one or more parent Crown corporations directly or indirectly through any number of subsidiaries each of which is wholly owned directly or indirectly by one or more parent Crown corporations.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Part, a corporation is wholly owned directly by the Crown if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all of the issued and outstanding shares of the corporation, other than shares necessary to qualify persons as directors, are held, otherwise than by way of security only, by, on behalf of or in trust for the Crown; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all the directors of the corporation, other than ex officio directors, are appointed by the Governor in Council or by a minister of the Crown with the approval of the Governor in Council.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (2), shares held by a corporation that is an agent of the Crown

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are deemed not to be held by or on behalf of the Crown; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are not by reason of that fact alone shares held in trust for the Crown.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Wholly owned by other corporation or corporations
Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Part, a corporation is wholly owned by one or more other corporations if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all of the issued and outstanding shares of the corporation, other than shares necessary to qualify persons as directors, are held, otherwise than by way of security only, by, on behalf of or in trust for the one or more other corporations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all the directors of the corporation are appointed by the board or boards of directors of the one or more other corporations; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all the directors of the one or more other corporations are, by virtue of their being directors of the one or more other corporations, directors of the corporation.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Part,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one corporation is an affiliate of another corporation if one of them is the subsidiary of the other or both are subsidiaries of the same corporation or each of them is controlled by the same person; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if two corporations are affiliates of the same corporation at the same time, they are deemed to be affiliates of each other.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Part, a corporation is a subsidiary of another corporation if it is controlled by that other corporation.
For the purposes of this Part, a corporation with share capital is controlled by a person if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shares of the corporation to which are attached more than fifty per cent of the votes that may be cast to elect directors of the corporation are held, otherwise than by way of security only, by, on behalf of or in trust for that person; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the votes attached to those shares are sufficient, if exercised, to elect a majority of the directors of the corporation.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Part, a corporation without share capital is controlled by a person if that person is able to appoint the majority of the directors of the corporation, whether or not he does so.

For the purposes of this Part, a person is deemed to be appointed by another person or group of persons if that person is appointed on the direction of that other person or group, whether or not he is actually appointed by that other person or group.

Where, in the opinion of the Governor in Council, a parent Crown corporation or a wholly-owned subsidiary of a parent Crown corporation carries on, or a parent Crown corporation and any wholly-owned subsidiary of the corporation carry on, more than one business or activity, the parent Crown corporation shall, with the approval of the Governor in Council, classify the businesses or activities for the purposes of this Part.

Section.Text: For greater certainty, this Part is binding on the Crown.

Subsection.Text: Divisions I to IV, except for sections 89.8 to 89.92, 131.1 and 154.01, do not apply to the Bank of Canada.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exemption for Canada Pension Plan Investment Board
Subsection.Text: Divisions I to IV, except for section 154.01, do not apply to the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board.

Divisions I to IV, except for sections 89.8 to 89.92, subsection 105(2) and sections 113.1, 119, 131 to 148 and 154.01, do not apply to the Canada Council for the Arts, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, the International Development Research Centre or the National Arts Centre Corporation.

Divisions I to IV, except for sections 89.8 to 89.92, subsection 105(2) and sections 113.1, 119, 131 to 148 and 154.01 and subject to subsection 21(2) of the Telefilm Canada Act, do not apply to Telefilm Canada.
Divisions I to V do not apply to any Crown corporation incorporated or acquired, with the written authorization of the appropriate Minister,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by or on behalf of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police for the purpose of performing its functions under the laws of Canada; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by or on behalf of any service established by an Act of Parliament to collect information and intelligence respecting the security of Canada.

Subsection.Text: Divisions I to IV do not apply to a member institution, as defined in section 2 of the Canada Deposit Insurance Corporation Act, any shares of which are held by the Canada Deposit Insurance Corporation as the result of the granting of an exemption referred to in section 10.01 of that Act.
Divisions I to IV do not apply to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a federal member institution, within the meaning assigned to that expression by section 2 of the Canada Deposit Insurance Corporation Act, the shares of which have been vested in the Canada Deposit Insurance Corporation by order of the Governor in Council under section 39.13 of that Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to the Canada Deposit Insurance Corporation, as a parent Crown corporation in respect of a wholly-owned subsidiary that is a federal member institution described in paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: Sections 88 and 89.2 to 104 and Divisions II to IV do not apply to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a bridge institution, as defined in section 2 of the Canada Deposit Insurance Corporation Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Canada Deposit Insurance Corporation, as a parent Crown corporation in respect of a wholly-owned subsidiary that is a bridge institution.

Subsection.Text: Each parent Crown corporation shall take such steps in relation to the articles, by-laws and management of each wholly-owned subsidiary of the corporation, if any, as are necessary to ensure that the businesses, activities and other affairs of the subsidiary are carried on in accordance with this Part and the regulations.

The Governor in Council may declare any provision of this Part that applies only to parent Crown corporations to apply to a wholly-owned subsidiary, and the provision applies, with such modifications as the circumstances require, to that wholly-owned subsidiary as if it were a parent Crown corporation.

Section.Text: Except as otherwise expressly provided, in the event of any inconsistency between the provisions of this Part and the provisions of any other Act of Parliament, the provisions of this Part prevail.
Each Crown corporation is ultimately accountable, through the appropriate Minister, to Parliament for the conduct of its affairs.

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the appropriate Minister, give a directive to any parent Crown corporation, if the Governor in Council is of the opinion that it is in the public interest to do so.
Before a directive is given to a parent Crown corporation, the appropriate Minister shall consult the board of directors of the corporation with respect to the content and effect of the directive.

The appropriate Minister shall cause a copy of any directive given to a parent Crown corporation to be laid before each House of Parliament on any of the first fifteen days on which that House is sitting after the directive is given.

Forthwith after implementing a directive and completing any actions required to be taken in connection therewith, a parent Crown corporation shall notify the appropriate Minister that the directive has been implemented.
No directive shall be given to the Standards Council of Canada with respect to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the manner in which voluntary standardization is promoted; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the provision of financial assistance to or for the benefit of a particular person or group of persons.

Subsection.Text: The directors of a parent Crown corporation to which a directive is given shall ensure that the directive is implemented in a prompt and efficient manner and, if in so doing they act in accordance with section 115, they are not accountable for any consequences arising from the implementation of the directive.
Compliance by a parent Crown corporation with a directive is deemed to be in the best interests of the corporation.
In this section, directive means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a directive given pursuant to subsection 89(1), 94(2) or 114(3);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a direction given under subsection 5(2) of the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation Act, subsection 9(2) of the Canadian Commercial Corporation Act or subsection 11(1) of the Canadian Dairy Commission Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a directive given under subsection 22(1) of the Canada Post Corporation Act.

Heading.TitleText: Implementation of World Trade Organization Agreement

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding subsections 85(1) to (1.2), the Governor in Council may give a directive pursuant to subsection 89(1) to any parent Crown corporation for the purpose of implementing any provision of the WTO Agreement that pertains to that Crown corporation.

The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Treasury Board and the appropriate Minister made at the request of a Crown corporation, make such regulations in relation to that corporation as the Governor in Council considers necessary for the purpose of implementing any provision of the WTO Agreement that pertains to that corporation.
In subsections (1) and (2), WTO Agreement has the meaning given to the word Agreement by subsection 2(1) of the World Trade Organization Agreement Implementation Act.

Heading.TitleText: Implementation of Agreement on Internal Trade

Section.Text: Notwithstanding subsections 85(1) to (1.2), the Governor in Council may give a directive pursuant to subsection 89(1) to any parent Crown corporation for the purpose of implementing any provision of the Agreement as that term is defined in section 2 of the Agreement on Internal Trade Implementation Act that pertains to that Crown corporation.

Heading.TitleText: Implementation of Canada-Chile Free Trade Agreement

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding subsections 85(1) to (1.2), the Governor in Council may give a directive under subsection 89(1) to any parent Crown corporation for the purpose of implementing any provision of the Canada-Chile Free Trade Agreement that pertains to that Crown corporation.

The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Treasury Board and the appropriate Minister made at the request of a Crown corporation, make such regulations in relation to that corporation as the Governor in Council considers necessary for the purpose of implementing any provision of the Canada-Chile Free Trade Agreement that pertains to that corporation.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Definition of Canada-Chile Free Trade Agreement
Subsection.Text: In subsections (1) and (2), Canada-Chile Free Trade Agreement has the meaning given to the word Agreement by subsection 2(1) of the Canada-Chile Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act.

Heading.TitleText: Implementation of Canada–Colombia Free Trade Agreement

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding subsections 85(1) to (1.2), the Governor in Council may give a directive under subsection 89(1) to any parent Crown corporation for the purpose of implementing any provision of the Canada–Colombia Free Trade Agreement that pertains to that Crown corporation.

The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Treasury Board and the appropriate Minister made at the request of a Crown corporation, make any regulations in relation to that corporation that the Governor in Council considers necessary for the purpose of implementing any provision of the Canada–Colombia Free Trade Agreement that pertains to that corporation.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Definition of Canada–Colombia Free Trade Agreement
Subsection.Text: In subsections (1) and (2), Canada–Colombia Free Trade Agreement has the same meaning as Agreement in section 2 of the Canada–Colombia Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act.

Heading.TitleText: Implementation of Canada — Costa Rica Free Trade Agreement

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding subsections 85(1) to (1.2), the Governor in Council may give a directive under subsection 89(1) to any parent Crown corporation for the purpose of implementing any provision of the Canada — Costa Rica Free Trade Agreement that pertains to that Crown corporation.

The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Treasury Board and the appropriate Minister made at the request of a Crown corporation, make such regulations in relation to that corporation as the Governor in Council considers necessary for the purpose of implementing any provision of the Canada — Costa Rica Free Trade Agreement that pertains to that corporation.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Definition of Canada — Costa Rica Free Trade Agreement
Subsection.Text: In subsections (1) and (2), Canada — Costa Rica Free Trade Agreement has the meaning given to the word Agreement by subsection 2(1) of the Canada — Costa Rica Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act.

Heading.TitleText: Implementation of Canada–Peru Free Trade Agreement

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding subsections 85(1) to (1.2), the Governor in Council may give a directive under subsection 89(1) to any parent Crown corporation for the purpose of implementing any provision of the Canada–Peru Free Trade Agreement that pertains to that Crown corporation.

The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Treasury Board and the appropriate Minister made at the request of a Crown corporation, make any regulations in relation to that corporation that the Governor in Council considers necessary for the purpose of implementing any provision of the Canada–Peru Free Trade Agreement that pertains to that corporation.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Definition of Canada–Peru Free Trade Agreement
Subsection.Text: In subsections (1) and (2), Canada–Peru Free Trade Agreement has the same meaning as Agreement in section 2 of the Canada–Peru Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act.

Heading.TitleText: Implementation of Other Free Trade Agreements

Subsection.Text: Despite subsections 85(1) to (1.2), the Governor in Council may give a directive under subsection 89(1) to any parent Crown corporation for the purpose of implementing any provision of a free trade agreement set out in Schedule VII that pertains to that Crown corporation.

The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Treasury Board and the appropriate Minister made at the request of a Crown corporation, make any regulations in relation to that corporation that the Governor in Council considers necessary for the purpose of implementing any provision of a free trade agreement set out in Schedule VII that pertains to that corporation.

Heading.TitleText: Orders — Terms and Conditions of Employment

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may, by order, direct a Crown corporation to have its negotiating mandate approved by the Treasury Board for the purpose of the Crown corporation entering into a collective agreement with a bargaining agent for a bargaining unit.

If the Governor in Council directs a Crown corporation to have its negotiating mandate approved, the Treasury Board may impose any requirement on the Crown corporation with respect to that negotiating mandate.

If the Governor in Council directs a Crown corporation to have its negotiating mandate approved, the Treasury Board may require that an employee under the jurisdiction of the Secretary of the Treasury Board attend and observe the collective bargaining between the Crown corporation and the bargaining agent, in which case that employee is entitled to do so.
A Crown corporation that is subject to an order made under subsection (1) may enter into a collective agreement referred to in the order only with the Treasury Board’s approval.

The Governor in Council may, by order, direct a Crown corporation to obtain the Treasury Board’s approval before the Crown corporation fixes the terms and conditions of employment of its non-unionized employees who are not appointed by the Governor in Council.

If the Governor in Council directs a Crown corporation to obtain the Treasury Board’s approval, the Treasury Board may impose any requirement on the Crown corporation with respect to the terms and conditions of employment of those employees.

The directors of a Crown corporation that is subject to an order made under subsection 89.8(1) or 89.9(1) shall ensure that subsection 89.8(4), the order and any requirement imposed under subsection 89.8(2) or 89.9(2) are complied with and, if in so doing they act in accordance with section 115, they are not accountable for any consequences arising from that compliance.
Compliance by a Crown corporation with subsection 89.8(4), the order or the requirement is deemed to be in the best interests of the corporation.

Section.Text: For greater certainty, including for the purposes of the Canada Labour Code, the Treasury Board is neither the employer of the employees of the Crown corporation that is subject to an order made under subsection 89.8(1) or 89.9(1) nor an employer representative of the Crown corporation or a person acting on the Crown corporation’s behalf.

Subsection.Text: No person shall, unless authorized by an Act of Parliament,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: procure the incorporation of a corporation any shares of which, on incorporation, would be held by, on behalf of or in trust for the Crown;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: acquire shares of a corporation that, on acquisition, would be held by, on behalf of or in trust for the Crown;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: apply for articles that would add to or otherwise make a material change in the objects or purposes for which a parent Crown corporation is incorporated, or the restrictions on the businesses or activities that a parent Crown corporation may carry on, as set out in its articles;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: sell or otherwise dispose of any shares of a parent Crown corporation; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: procure the dissolution or amalgamation of a parent Crown corporation.

Subsection.Text: No parent Crown corporation shall, unless authorized by an Act of Parliament, sell or otherwise dispose of all or substantially all of the assets of the corporation.

Subject to subsection (2), no corporation, or corporations, in a related group shall, unless authorized by an Act of Parliament, sell or otherwise dispose of any of the assets of the corporation or corporations, if the assets to be sold or otherwise disposed of constitute all or substantially all of the total assets of the group.
For the purposes of paragraphs (1)(a) and (b), shares held by a corporation that is an agent of the Crown

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are deemed not to be held by or on behalf of the Crown; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are not by reason of that fact alone shares held in trust for the Crown.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this section and sections 91 to 94,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a reference to an acquisition or a sale or other disposal includes an acquisition or a sale or other disposal

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: that is between agent corporations or between the Crown and an agent corporation, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: that occurs as a result of more than one related transaction or event;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a reference to the assets of a corporation or corporations includes shares of another corporation held by, on behalf of or in trust for the corporation or corporations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: person includes an agent of the Crown;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: related group means a group of corporations consisting of a parent Crown corporation and all of its wholly-owned subsidiaries; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: shares includes any conversion or exchange privilege, option or right to acquire shares.

Section.MarginalNote: Transactions requiring Governor in Council authorization

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 90, no parent Crown corporation or wholly-owned subsidiary of a parent Crown corporation shall, unless authorized by the Governor in Council,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: procure the incorporation of a corporation any shares of which, on incorporation, would be held by, on behalf of or in trust for the corporation or subsidiary;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: acquire shares of a corporation that, on acquisition, would be held by, on behalf of or in trust for the corporation or subsidiary;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: acquire all or substantially all of the assets of another corporation;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: sell or otherwise dispose of any shares of a wholly-owned subsidiary of the corporation; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: procure the dissolution or amalgamation of a wholly-owned subsidiary of the corporation.

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 90 and subsection (3), no corporation, or corporations, in a related group shall, unless authorized by the Governor in Council, sell or otherwise dispose of any of the assets of the corporation or corporations used in any major business or activity of the corporation or corporations, if the assets to be sold or otherwise disposed of constitute all or substantially all of the total assets of the group used in that major business or activity.
Subject to section 90, no wholly-owned subsidiary shall, unless authorized by the Governor in Council,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: sell or otherwise dispose of any shares of the subsidiary; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sell or otherwise dispose of all or substantially all of the assets of the subsidiary.

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 90, no person shall, unless authorized by the Governor in Council, apply for articles in respect of a parent Crown corporation.

Where a parent Crown corporation sets out the details of a proposed transaction in a corporate plan submitted pursuant to section 122, the Governor in Council, in addition to approving the plan under that section, may authorize a person to undertake the transaction for the purposes of this section.
No person shall be authorized under this section to undertake a transaction unless the Governor in Council is satisfied that the person is otherwise empowered to undertake the transaction.

The Governor in Council may, in any authorization under this section, specify such terms and conditions as the Governor in Council deems appropriate and may make the authorization either one of general application or in respect of any specified transaction or transactions.
Sections 90 and 91 do not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the acquisition of shares or assets by way of security only, or the sale or other disposal of shares or assets held by way of security only;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the acquisition or the sale or other disposal of shares or assets in the ordinary course of a business of providing financial assistance;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the acquisition or the sale or other disposal of shares or assets, if the acquisition, sale or disposal involves only

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a parent Crown corporation and one or more wholly-owned subsidiaries of the corporation, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: two or more wholly-owned subsidiaries

ContinuedParagraph.Text: and is made as part of a bona fide reorganization of the parent Crown corporation or wholly-owned subsidiaries;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the acquisition of shares by way of the exercise of any conversion or exchange privilege, option or right to acquire shares, if that privilege, option or right was acquired in accordance with section 90 or 91, as the case may be;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the acquisition of shares of a parent Crown corporation by the corporation; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the acquisition of shares of a wholly-owned subsidiary by the subsidiary, the parent Crown corporation that wholly owns the subsidiary or any other wholly-owned subsidiary of that parent Crown corporation.

Subsection.Text: Paragraphs 90(1)(b) and 91(1)(b) do not apply in respect of the nomination or appointment of a person to the board of directors or membership of a corporation, except where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a majority of the directors or members are nominated or appointed by or on behalf of the Crown or by directors or members who were nominated or appointed by or on behalf of the Crown; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Crown would otherwise obtain control of the corporation.

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may make regulations exempting a specified parent Crown corporation or wholly-owned subsidiary or a parent Crown corporation or wholly-owned subsidiary of a specified class from the application of section 91, either generally or in respect of any transaction of a specified class.
Where a person undertakes a transaction referred to in section 90 or 91, that person shall notify the prescribed person in accordance with the regulations.
For the purposes of subsection (1), the Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing the person to be notified and the time within which and manner in which that person is to be notified.

Notwithstanding section 90, where a parent Crown corporation is not named in Schedule III within a period of sixty days after its incorporation or acquisition, the directors and shareholders of the corporation shall forthwith after the expiration of that period take all steps necessary to dissolve the corporation.
Notwithstanding section 91, the Governor in Council may direct that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any wholly-owned subsidiary incorporated contrary to section 91 be dissolved or otherwise disposed of,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any shares of a corporation acquired contrary to section 91 be sold or otherwise disposed of,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any change effected by articles contrary to section 91 be reversed, or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any assets acquired contrary to section 91 be sold or otherwise disposed of,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: and the directors and shareholders of the corporation in respect of which the direction is given shall forthwith take all steps necessary to comply with the direction.

Subsection.Text: No parent Crown corporation or wholly-owned subsidiary of a parent Crown corporation shall carry on any business or activity that is not consistent with the objects or purposes for which the parent Crown corporation is incorporated, or the restrictions on the businesses or activities that it may carry on, as set out in its charter.

Subsection (1) shall not be construed as prohibiting or restricting a parent Crown corporation or wholly-owned subsidiary from continuing to carry on any business or activity that it carried on immediately before September 1, 1984.

Section.Text: An agent corporation may exercise its powers only as an agent of the Crown.
An agent corporation may enter into contracts in the name of the Crown or in the name of the corporation.

Actions, suits or other legal proceedings in respect of any right or obligation acquired or incurred by an agent corporation, whether in the name of the Crown or in the name of the corporation, may be brought or taken by or against the corporation in the name of the corporation in any court that would have jurisdiction if the corporation were not an agent of the Crown.

Subsection.Text: Where the title to property is held in the name of an agent corporation, that property is the property of the Crown.

Subject to this section and sections 90, 91 and 130, an agent corporation may sell or otherwise dispose of or lease any property held by the corporation and may retain and use the proceeds of the disposal or lease, but only

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with the regulations; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the authorization of the Governor in Council.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (2) does not apply in respect of any sale or other disposal or lease of property by an agent corporation established by an Act of Parliament, if the corporation is specifically empowered by that Act or any other Act of Parliament

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to sell or otherwise dispose of or lease property; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to sell or otherwise dispose of or lease property for consideration not exceeding a specified amount and the sale or other disposal or lease of the property is for consideration equal to or less than the specified amount.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (2), the Governor in Council may make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the terms and conditions on which an agent corporation may sell or otherwise dispose of or lease property;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the circumstances in which an agent corporation may retain and use all or any part of the proceeds of any disposal or lease of property; and
